messages.message:
For BAML have been asked to help define some of our metrics, is there specific defintions people prefer from online:
Accuracy:
Precision:
Recall:

Precision: Of the values IB extracted, what percentage should have been extracted?
Recall: Of the values that IB should have extracted, what percentage was extracted?
Accuracy: What percentage of the time does IB extract nothing when nothing should be extracted and extract the correct value when something should be extracted?

Agree with this chetan.

I prefer to discuss things like “doc-level accuracy” and “field-level accuracy”

Here are the numbers we often look at:
   “There are 50 docs”. Let’s say we got “employee_name” correct 40 times. That’s an 80% field-level accuracy for “employee_name”.

Now let’s say that we got “pay_date” correct 80% of the time (80% field level accuracy) — let’s now look at how many documents where we got ALL fields correct (e.g., 60% possibly in this case where both “pay_date” and “employee_name” are correct)

So we would have 60% doc level accuracy .

Finally, what if we misclassify a document and didn’t even do extraction?
What if we classified a document as “ADP” where it should have been “other”

For that, we have two metrics:
    False-positive rate. 2 / 100 docs were labeled as “ADP” but should have been “other”
    False-negative rate: 10 / 100 docs were labeled as “other” but should have been “ADP”

FYI @Kerry @Matt @Chetan — those are my thoughts on metrics we should track for customers
Correspondingly we also track recall for classification, e.g., “There were 100 ADP documents” and you only correctly classified “90" of them, so we only have 90% recall there
I have to think because we have to think what constitutes a quality document which the metrics can be applied to

oh gotcha — and finally we break down these metrics grouped by “LQ_doc”, “HQ_doc” and “MQ_doc”. Basically for “LQ_doc” we try not to make any promises about metrics there, and focus on “MQ_doc” and “HQ_docs”
